intro: Vaccinium platyphyllum, commonly known as the flat-leaved huckleberry, is a species of evergreen shrub native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes other well-known plants such as blueberries and cranberries. The plant is characterized by its small, oval-shaped leaves that are typically flat and leathery in texture. It produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that are usually pink or white, followed by edible berries that are typically dark blue to black in color. Vaccinium platyphyllum thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and streamside areas.
